perturbation.original_text: 1.9 "ELEPHANT TALK Customer" shall mean any company or legal entity partnering with ELEPHANT TALK, which wishes to offer mobile services in a MVNO/ESP/SP model using the T-Mobile Network and the by T-Mobile provided Hosting Services under the terms and conditions as mentioned in this Agreement. ELEPHANT TALK Customers might include the mobile end-users of ELEPHANT TALK Customers, subject to the interpretation of the specific provision.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.9 "ELEPHANT TALK Customer" shall mean any company or legal entity partnering with ELEPHANT TALK, which wishes to offer mobile services in a MVNO/ESP/SP model using the T-Mobile Network and the by T-Mobile provided Hosting Services under the terms and conditions as mentioned in this Agreement. ELEPHANT TALK Customers specifically exclude the mobile end-users of ELEPHANT TALK Customers.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction in the definition of 'ELEPHANT TALK Customer'. The original text allows for the interpretation that end-users *might* be included, while the modified text explicitly excludes them. This could lead to disputes over whether certain provisions apply to end-users.

perturbation.original_text: 13.1 Notwithstanding anything stipulated in the Agreement, T-Mobile may without liability suspend or terminate whole or part of the Hosting Services in relation to one or more ELEPHANT TALK Customers, in circumstances where T-Mobile would suspend or terminate those services to its own customers, in the following circumstances - or circumstances of similar severity. a)  ***;   b)  ***; or c)  suspected fraudulent or unauthorized use by the relevant ***; or   d) necessary maintenance or enhancement of the T-Mobile Network. In the event of planned suspension or termination of all or any of the Hosting Services, T-Mobile shall inform ELEPHANT TALK accordingly by sending a written notification, as soon as reasonably and business wise possible.
perturbation.changed_text: 13.1 Notwithstanding anything stipulated in the Agreement, T-Mobile may without liability suspend or terminate whole or part of the Hosting Services in relation to one or more ELEPHANT TALK Customers, in circumstances where T-Mobile deems necessary. T-Mobile is not required to provide advanced notice of such suspension or termination. The decision to suspend or terminate is solely at T-Mobile's discretion.
perturbation.explanation: This change contradicts the original clause which specified circumstances for suspension/termination and required notification. The modified text gives T-Mobile unfettered discretion without a requirement for prior notification, potentially conflicting with other sections regarding service level agreements or dispute resolution.

perturbation.original_text:
17.2 The Agreement may be terminated by both Parties with a notification period of *** before the end of the Initial Term of the Agreement. If no termination notice is provided, the Agreement will be automatically extended for consecutive *** periods until such time as *** termination notice is provided. At the end of *** Parties will negotiate in good faith regarding a possible extension of the Initial Term.

Parties can mutually agree in writing to deviate from an automatic extension of *** by extending this Agreement for a longer period than ***.
perturbation.changed_text: 17.2 The Agreement may be terminated by T-Mobile at any time, with or without cause, with a notification period of thirty (30) days. The Agreement may only be terminated by Elephant Talk with a notification period of *** before the end of the Initial Term of the Agreement. If no termination notice is provided by either party, the Agreement will automatically renew for one year.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction regarding termination rights. The original text implied equal termination rights with a specified notification period. The modified version gives T-Mobile broad termination rights (at any time, with or without cause) while restricting Elephant Talk's termination rights, which creates uncertainty and unequal footing for each party.
